cmis:value.sf:invariantValue: Quantum launches new business notebook "Gluon"

cmis:propertyString.cmis:value: Quantum lanza un nuevo portátil de negocios "Gluon"

cmis:value.sf:invariantValue: Gail Thomas

A division of Quantum Inc., today announced the general availability of its new business tablet, the Axion, designed for today's innovative, business user in need of added functionality, performance and reliability.

cmis:propertyString.cmis:value: A division of Quantum Inc., today announced the general availability of its new business tablet, the Axion, designed for today's innovative, business user in need of added functionality, performance and reliability.

cmis:value.sf:invariantValue:
A division of Quantum Inc., today announced the general availability of its new business tablet, the Axion, designed for today's innovative, business user in need of added functionality, performance and reliability. Building on the success of its predecessor, the Axion Tablet is full performance including the latest technologies. With its compact design and 7–inch diagonal LED backlit display, the Axion Tablet is easy to carry to and from the classroom and is designed to sustain the typical bumps and spills thanks to Quantum's security technology. The Axion Tablet comes in configurations with Titanium Silver.

Multi-Touch and Feature Rich: Axion is equipped to handle any task. A unique finish helps reduce fingerprints and improves grip. Continuing to provide unique organizational tools and easy access to content, Quantums and ReelTime software offer the latest in Toshiba innovation.

With its compact design and 7–inch diagonal LED backlit display, the Axion Tablet is easy to carry to and from the classroom and is designed to sustain the typical bumps and spills thanks to Quantum's security technology. The Axion Tablet comes in configurations with Titanium Silver.

Multi-Touch and Feature Rich: Axion is equipped to handle any task. A unique finish helps reduce fingerprints and improves grip. Continuing to provide unique organizational tools and easy access to content, Quantums and ReelTime software offer the latest in Toshiba innovation.

Green tech innovators use the latest environmental science and green chemistry to reduce the harmful impact of human activity on the earth

cmis:propertyString.cmis:value: Green tech innovators use the latest environmental science and green chemistry to reduce the harmful impact of human activity on the earth

cmis:value.sf:invariantValue:
What is eco-friendly technology? Also known as clean tech, green tech and environmental tech, eco-friendly technology can help preserve the environment through energy efficiency and reduction of harmful waste. Green tech innovators use the latest environmental science and green chemistry to reduce the harmful impact of human activity on the earth.

Green technology is still in the earliest stages of development, but many exciting innovations have already been made in areas like renewable energy, water purification and waste management, as well as in everyday consumer products like electronics and vehicles. It can be as small as a hand-held gadget or as expansive as a new method of filtering greenhouse gases out of the atmosphere.

So what is your take. Let's say you recycle your laptop and then get a new one immediately for half the price. Would you be in for that?

cmis:propertyString.cmis:value:
Qué es la tecnología respetuosa del medio ambiente? También conocida como tecnología limpia, tecnología verde y tecnología del medio ambiente, la tecnología respetuosa del medio ambiente puede ayudar a preservar el medio ambiente a través de la eficiencia energética y la reducción de desechos peligrosos. los innovadores de tecnología verde utilizan la última ciencia del medio ambiente y la química verde para reducir los efectos perjudiciales de la actividad humana sobre la tierra.
La tecnología verde se encuentra todavía en las primeras etapas de desarrollo, pero muchas innovaciones interesantes ya se han realizado en áreas como la energía renovable, la purificación del agua y gestión de residuos, así como en productos de consumo diario, como la electrónica y vehículos. Puede ser tan pequeña como un dispositivo de mano o tan amplias como un nuevo método de filtrado de gases de efecto invernadero de la atmósfera.
Entonces, cuál es su opinión? Digamos que usted recicla su computadora portátil y luego obtiene una nueva inmediatamente por la mitad del precio. Estaría usted a eso?

Most current conversational user experiences are based around small snippets of micro-copy. In a conversational user experience, you’ll never need to understand the hamburger menu, because there won’t be one

cmis:propertyString.cmis:value: Most current conversational user experiences are based around small snippets of micro-copy. In a conversational user experience, you’ll never need to understand the hamburger menu, because there won’t be one

cmis:value.sf:invariantValue:
One of the biggest buzz phrases at the moment is “Conversational UX”. It refers to a user experience in which your interaction with a company, or service, is automated based on your prior behavior.

Contrary to the implication in the title, a conversational UX doesn’t have to be a literal conversation, the term refers to back and forth interaction in which both parties come to understand each other.

Most current conversational user experiences are based around small snippets of micro-copy. In a conversational user experience, you’ll never need to understand the hamburger menu, because there won’t be one, the app—web, or native—will simply adapt to your inquiries. And if device operating systems follow suit, you may not even download apps, your OS will simply determine which apps and services to use on your behalf, based on prior usage.

A conversational UX is more responsive than any existing app or site. A conversational UX can have the same interaction as a million call centers, without the need for hold music, security questions, or checking with its supervisor. A conversational UX doesn’t need onboarding and won’t suffer the same drop-off rates as apps, because it will adapt to the user’s (or programmer’s) needs. The economic reality is that any task that can be automated, will be automated.

The one weakness of a conversational UX is that we don’t trust AI. Trust is a core value of any successful user experience. Connecting on an emotional level is the ultimate tool of most design processes; one of the reasons the term “UX” has outgrown “UI” is that the former implies empathy, the latter implies mere utility. Whether it’s a luddite’s aversion to new technology, or too many ‘80s sci-fi movies, we always suspect an ulterior motive. As Ripley discovered, behind every Bishop there’s a Weyland-Yutani.

So we might allow a conversational UX to buy our weekly groceries for us, but would we let one buy our clothes? Book our vacation? Select our college major?

We’re talking about conversational UX now, because the bots that power it are reaching the point of viability. No, they can’t pass the Turing Test, but they really don’t need to. In fact, the current obvious flaws in AI may be precisely what powers the bot revolution.

Conversational UX is so flawed at present, that mistaking a bot for a human is tantamount to being outwitted by a lamppost. The time is ripe for conversational UX, precisely because we can still identify it for what it is; we don’t feel deceived. As Asimov predicted, we like robots that can be readily identified as robots.

The key to conversational UX may be a transparently bot-like personality. Ironically, the most successful conversational UX may be the one that learns to act dumb.

Google Fonts announced that it had debuted a new look that would streamline browsing for new fonts. People who need fonts for their sites or applications now have a much more accessible service to use.

cmis:propertyString.cmis:value: Google Fonts announced that it had debuted a new look that would streamline browsing for new fonts. People who need fonts for their sites or applications now have a much more accessible service to use.

cmis:value.sf:invariantValue:
Google Fonts is the latest Google service that’s gotten a design makeover. The directory of free web fonts makes it a cinch for designers to customize fonts, share fonts with their colleagues, and even collaborate on fonts with the original designer.

In a tweet on its official Twitter stream, Google Fonts announced that it had debuted a new look that would streamline browsing for new fonts. People who need fonts for their sites or applications now have a much more accessible service to use.

When you compare the old version of Fonts to the new version, the contrast is notable.The new design is defined by less clutter, more colors, and a cleaner user experience.

Whereas the old version showcased typefaces in rectangular boxes from left to right, the new version makes sensible use of card-based design to both organize and show off Google’s family of open-source fonts. The overall result is a presentation that has to contend with less clutter, which makes it easier for designers, developers and users to navigate through the site to find fonts they like.

The shift of the main content to the center of the page allows the use of white space to be really effective. In the old design, white space was unfocused as different page elements competed for attention.

Minimalism

The new design features less navigation than the old design. Whereas there was a navigation bar that let designers see various typefaces in action based on words, sentences, paragraphs and poster tabs, all of this has been removed in the new rollout. Instead, designers now only get to see the display choices when they hover their cursors on the actual font cards; there, they’ll be greeted with different drop-down boxes for the preview text and styles.

The size-selection dropdown box has been removed and is now a single slider in every card. Further, the filters dealing with different categories and how to sort all the fonts have been moved from the left sidebar to the right sidebar.

 

Color

Perhaps in keeping with its Material Design sensibilities, Google has also introduced more color into its Fonts service. The old design only featured blue and white, which made the use of white space ineffective since most of the page was white anyway.

A welcome sight for designers who want a hassle free experience

The new design allows users to pick their color scheme: Clicking on the “change background color” icon will let users choose between pink, black, blue and yellow for the background. All display good contrast, but some background colors work better than others.

 

UX

The UX is really what matters most at the end of the day. Google Fonts’ redesign has improved the UX to maximum efficiency. When designers are interested in a font, they can click on “see specimen” to arrive on a new page that tells them all the font particulars as well as info on the typeface designer. The old version actually used popup windows to present the same info.

Users also have the option to hide the search bar, which the old design didn’t allow.

All in all, the Fonts update should be a welcome sight for designers who want a hassle-free experience in choosing a new font for their web projects. The clean design helps deliver an improved UX that makes navigation easier.

Whereas the old version showcased typefaces in rectangular boxes from left to right, the new version makes sensible use of card-based design to both organize and show off Google’s family of open-source fonts. The overall result is a presentation that has to contend with less clutter, which makes it easier for designers, developers and users to navigate through the site to find fonts they like.

The shift of the main content to the center of the page allows the use of white space to be really effective. In the old design, white space was unfocused as different page elements competed for attention.

Minimalism

The new design features less navigation than the old design. Whereas there was a navigation bar that let designers see various typefaces in action based on words, sentences, paragraphs and poster tabs, all of this has been removed in the new rollout. Instead, designers now only get to see the display choices when they hover their cursors on the actual font cards; there, they’ll be greeted with different drop-down boxes for the preview text and styles.

The size-selection dropdown box has been removed and is now a single slider in every card. Further, the filters dealing with different categories and how to sort all the fonts have been moved from the left sidebar to the right sidebar.

 

Color

Perhaps in keeping with its Material Design sensibilities, Google has also introduced more color into its Fonts service. The old design only featured blue and white, which made the use of white space ineffective since most of the page was white anyway.

A welcome sight for designers who want a hassle free experience

The new design allows users to pick their color scheme: Clicking on the “change background color” icon will let users choose between pink, black, blue and yellow for the background. All display good contrast, but some background colors work better than others.

 

UX

The UX is really what matters most at the end of the day. Google Fonts’ redesign has improved the UX to maximum efficiency. When designers are interested in a font, they can click on “see specimen” to arrive on a new page that tells them all the font particulars as well as info on the typeface designer. The old version actually used popup windows to present the same info.

Users also have the option to hide the search bar, which the old design didn’t allow.

All in all, the Fonts update should be a welcome sight for designers who want a hassle-free experience in choosing a new font for their web projects. The clean design helps deliver an improved UX that makes navigation easier.

cmis:propertyString.cmis:value:
Fuentes de Google es el último servicio de Google que ha conseguido una renovación de diseño. El directorio de fuentes libres de la tela hace que sea muy fácil para los diseñadores para personalizar las fuentes, fuentes compartir con sus colegas, e incluso colaborar en fuentes con el diseñador original.
En un tweet en su Twitter oficial corriente, fuentes de Google anunció que había debutado un nuevo aspecto a fin de agilizar su búsqueda de nuevas fuentes. Las personas que necesitan fuentes para sus sitios o aplicaciones ahora tienen un servicio mucho más accesible para su uso.
Cuando se compara la versión antigua de Fuentes a la nueva versión, el contraste es notable.The nuevo diseño se define por menos desorden, más colores, y una experiencia de usuario más clara.

Mientras que la versión anterior mostró tipos de letra en las cajas rectangulares de izquierda a derecha, la nueva versión hace uso sensato de diseño basado en la tarjeta para tanto organizar y mostrar familia de fuentes de código abierto de Google. El resultado global es una presentación que tiene que lidiar con menos desorden, lo que hace que sea más fácil para los diseñadores, desarrolladores y los usuarios navegar a través del sitio para encontrar fuentes que les gusta.
El cambio del contenido principal del centro de la página permite el uso de espacios en blanco para ser realmente eficaz. En el viejo diseño, espacio en blanco estaba fuera de foco como los diferentes elementos de la página competían por la atención.
minimalismo
El nuevo diseño de navegación menos que el diseño anterior. Mientras que había una barra de navegación que permiten a los diseñadores ver diferentes tipos de letra en la acción sobre la base de palabras, frases, párrafos y pestañas de carteles, todo esto ha sido eliminado en el nuevo despliegue. En lugar de ello, los diseñadores ahora sólo se llega a ver las opciones de visualización cuando se pasa el cursor cursores en las tarjetas de fuentes reales; allí, que será recibido con diferentes cuadros desplegables para el texto de vista previa y estilos.
El cuadro desplegable de selección de tamaño se ha eliminado y ahora es una sola barra de desplazamiento en cada tarjeta. Además, los filtros se ocupan de diferentes categorías y cómo ordenar todas las fuentes se han movido desde la barra lateral izquierda de la barra lateral derecha.
 
Color
Tal vez, en consonancia con sus sensibilidades Material Design, Google también ha introducido más color en su servicio de Fuentes. El diseño de edad sólo se contó con azul y blanco, lo que hizo que el uso de espacio en blanco ineficaces ya que la mayoría de la página era blanco de todos modos.
Una vista agradable para los diseñadores que quieren una experiencia libre de problemas
El nuevo diseño permite a los usuarios elegir su combinación de colores: Al hacer clic en el icono de "cambio de color de fondo" permitirá a los usuarios elegir entre rosa, negro, azul y amarillo para el fondo. Todos muestran un buen contraste, pero algunos colores de fondo funcionan mejor que otros.
 
UX
El UX es realmente lo que más importa al final del día. rediseño de Fuentes de Google 'ha mejorado la UX para una máxima eficiencia. Cuando los diseñadores están interesados en un tipo de letra, se puede hacer clic en "ver" ejemplar para llegar a una nueva página que les dice todos los detalles del tipo de letra, así como información sobre el diseñador tipográfico. La versión antigua de hecho utiliza ventanas emergentes para presentar la misma información.
Los usuarios también tienen la opción de ocultar la barra de búsqueda, que el diseño anterior no permitía.
Con todo, la actualización Fuentes debe ser una vista agradable para los diseñadores que desean una experiencia sin problemas en la elección de un nuevo tipo de letra para sus proyectos web. El diseño limpio ayuda a producir un UX mejorado que facilita la navegación.

cmis:value.sf:invariantValue: Google Fonts unveils huge redesign

cmis:propertyString.cmis:value: Fuentes de Google desvela gran rediseño

cmis:value.sf:invariantValue: Marc Schenker

The value of the pop-up to designers is obvious: a piece of information that doesn’t need to be on screen all the time, doesn’t need to displace other more permanent elements of the design; creating its own window gives it temporary space, and the required prominence, without interrupting the rest of the layout.

cmis:propertyString.cmis:value: The value of the pop-up to designers is obvious: a piece of information that doesn’t need to be on screen all the time, doesn’t need to displace other more permanent elements of the design; creating its own window gives it temporary space, and the required prominence, without interrupting the rest of the layout.

cmis:value.sf:invariantValue:
Despite valiant efforts to come up with an alternative approach, pop-ups still infest the web. It seems like every site you visit wants you to sign up for a newsletter, take advantage of an offer, visit a sponsor, or provide feedback—all before you’ve actually reached the content you arrived to see.

The value of the pop-up to designers is obvious: a piece of information that doesn’t need to be on screen all the time, doesn’t need to displace other more permanent elements of the design; creating its own window gives it temporary space, and the required prominence, without interrupting the rest of the layout.

Pop-ups can easily be dismissed, often simply by clicking anywhere but on the pop-up. Psychologically they partition content, allow for competition entries, logins, and the like, to be focussed on for a short period of time. Pop-ups also neatly side-step the issue of opening new windows, maintaining a single session and preventing users from passively navigating away from a site.

But pop-ups are also intrusive. They’re a lot like a waiter that tries to take your order before you’ve taken off your jacket. They’re easy to apply to a site with minimal disruption, but easy solutions are rarely good solutions.

Usability testing tends to show that users dislike pop-ups—closing them as soon as possible—but that they also tend to understand them, perhaps because they mimic the basic UI of the OS.

With usability so high on everyone’s agenda, did pop-ups simply evolve at the right time? Are they a stable design pattern, or a particularly persistent design trend?

cmis:propertyString.cmis:value:
A pesar de los valientes esfuerzos para llegar a un enfoque alternativo, pop-ups todavía infestan la web. Parece que cada sitio que visita usted quiere suscribirse a un boletín de noticias, tomar ventaja de una oferta, visite uno de los patrocinadores, o proporcionar retroalimentación en todo antes de que haya alcanzado realmente el contenido que llegó a ver.

El valor de la emergente para los diseñadores es obvia: una pieza de información que no necesita estar en pantalla todo el tiempo, no tiene que desplazar a otros elementos más permanentes del diseño; la creación de su propia ventana que da espacio temporal, y la prominencia requerida, sin interrumpir el resto del diseño.

Las ventanas emergentes pueden ser fácilmente despedidos, a menudo simplemente haciendo clic en cualquier lugar, pero en la ventana emergente. Psicológicamente dividan contenido, permiten entradas de la competencia, nombres de usuarios, y similares, que se centró en un corto período de tiempo. Pop-ups se integra perfectamente a esquivar la cuestión de la apertura de nuevas ventanas, manteniendo una sola sesión y evitando que los usuarios de forma pasiva navegar fuera de un sitio.
Sin embargo, las ventanas emergentes también son intrusivos. Son muy parecido a un camarero que intenta llevar a su fin antes de que haya tomado fuera de su chaqueta. Son fáciles de aplicar a un sitio con una interrupción mínima, pero rara vez son soluciones fáciles buenas soluciones.

Las pruebas de usabilidad tiende a demostrar que no les gusta a los usuarios las ventanas emergentes de cierre tan pronto como sea posible, sino que también tienden a entenderlos, tal vez porque imitan la interfaz de usuario básica del sistema operativo.
Con la facilidad de uso tan alto en la agenda de todos, tenían las ventanas emergentes simplemente evolucionan en el momento adecuado? ¿Son un patrón de diseño estable, o una tendencia de diseño particularmente persistente?

cmis:value.sf:invariantValue: Poll: Are pop-ups here to stay?

cmis:propertyString.cmis:value: Encuesta: ¿Son las ventanas emergentes aquí para quedarse?

cmis:value.sf:invariantValue: Ben Moss

At some point, most creative professionals (e.g. designers, developers, copywriters, etc.) will run into the customer from hell. These are the customers who, once they’re inside your business, bring in 20 percent of your income and 80 percent of your headaches.

cmis:propertyString.cmis:value: At some point, most creative professionals (e.g. designers, developers, copywriters, etc.) will run into the customer from hell. These are the customers who, once they’re inside your business, bring in 20 percent of your income and 80 percent of your headaches.

cmis:value.sf:invariantValue:
Have you ever had a customer from hell? The kind of customer who abuses you, spending as little as they possibly can while trying to squeeze as much free work out of you as possible?

You’re not alone.

At some point, most creative professionals (e.g. designers, developers, copywriters, etc.) will run into the customer from hell. These are the customers who, once they’re inside your business, bring in 20 percent of your income and 80 percent of your headaches.

Customers today are abusive, entitled and demanding… right? Actually no…

Customers as a whole are patient, kind and understanding. When they buy into you, into your business, they’re game changers. These customers have the power to literally change your business for the better, over night. I just mentioned the customer from hell though. Am I talking out both sides of my mouth? Not at all: The customers from hell? They aren’t customers…they’re predators.

These customers come in five deadly flavors, but their goal is the same. Take as much as they can from you, give as little as they can in return. Ruthless and simple. What’s not so simple is how they find you.

Most people have serious misconceptions about these predators. Their mistaken ideas keep them in the dark, which is exactly what these thirsty bloodsuckers want. Most of us recognize these predators when they’re in our business, but by then it’s too late.

If you’re clueless about them, you’re clueless about how they work — which means you can’t stop them, especially if you believe in these myths:

  • It’s a customer service issue: “If we’re just able to keep them happy we won’t have a problem.”
  • All customers are basically good: “If we’re good to them they’ll be good to us.”
  • Make customers the priority: “Put customers first and they’ll reward you” or “the customer is always right.”

So what’s the problem then? What attracts them to your business?

Marketing. Haphazard marketing sucks these predators in. The term “marketing” means anything you’re doing to close new clients. Your emails, proposals, blog posts, forum posts, anything. 

And the worst part?

Most freelancers have no idea their marketing attracts the wrong customer. But how? Are these predators all the same? Should you work with them or weed them out? Knowing who you’re fighting dictates how you fight.

Let’s start with the first predator.

 

1) The Arranger (manipulates deals, circumstances and events)

These predators want any project, any circumstance to be win/lose in their favor. If you have an agreement they’ll change the terms and conditions. They demand options that don’t exist and push for concessions that really only benefit them.

The Arranger looks for two things:

  • Freelancers afraid to lose their business. Every project is an amazing opportunity when there aren’t enough clients. Arrangers use this fear to wear you down, chipping away at you until you’re psychologically exhausted.
  • An unhealthy desire to be flexible. Need this 300 page site in 48 hours? Sure! Established freelancers use a “take it or leave it” philosophy. Arrangers use “flexible freelancers” as cheap labor.

 

2) The Corrupter (a dirty, rotten liar)

They’ll say or do anything to get what they want. They’ll lie to you or about you. They’ll steal from you, turn customers and vendors against you, use entrapment – nothing is off limits for them.

The Corrupter looks for two things:

  • Fear of Conflict. The Corrupter loves to cross the line. They’ll invade your boundaries, cross ethical and moral lines and provoke fights. Carefully monitoring your response. A fear of conflict tells them it’s okay to steam roll over you.
  • Unfair exchange. Give Corrupters a discount, concession or deal and they keep pushing. Put conditions or limits on what you’re willing to give them and they become vicious.

 

3) The Disrupter (demands control)

These predators require special treatment. They want to be in charge. They refuse to use your product or service as intended. They demand your co-workers, partners or employees ignore your requests. For Disrupters, control is everything.

Marketing that attracts The Disrupter:

Disrupters target freelancers with strong “peace keeping” or “fun loving” temperaments. Prefer to avoid conflict or focus on having fun? Disrupters demand you do things their way.

Messages like “have it your way”, “designed around you” and “you’re the boss” are lightning rods that attract The Disrupter.

If you’re a freelancer with a strong perfectionist or control temperament, you’re much harder to control. Focus on “keeping the peace” to win a customer and you’re theirs.

 

4) The Slanderer (punishes you with shame and guilt)

The Slanderer is a professional troll. They’ll provoke you. Imply that you’ve let them down. They’ll bully you, spread gossip and pick fights—they want you to explode.

When you do they have the justification they need to demand discounts, ask for free products and “renegotiate” contracts: “Why do you charge 10x as much for the same service?” “I gave you a chance when no one else would. Is this how you repay me?” “My company pays your bills.” “How do you justify not including that feature? That’s robbery!”

Marketing that attracts The Slanderer:

As a freelancer you’re unique. That’s obvious to you but it’s something customers can’t see. What’s worse, your uniqueness needs to accomplish two clear goals.

  • Something customers care about. Your uniqueness solves customer problems or attracts them in some way.
  • They’re willing to pay for it. It tells you that customers value your work and they’re willing to take a risk with you.

Marketing pieces that say things like “we guarantee your satisfaction”, “we never stop working for you” or “our customers are number one” attract slanderers.

They see this lack of uniqueness as potential desperation. They believe there’s nothing special about you as a freelancer. So they’ll remind you over and over in different ways, until they’re able to get what they want.

 

5) The Schemer (exploits loopholes)

Agreements were created for them. They’re incredibly resourceful; they’ll find a way over, under, around or through your boundaries. Don’t do spec work? “You should have told me.” Offer a 30 day money back guarantee? They’ll use your rules against you. They’ll squeeze out 60 days of free work, then on day 59 ask for a full refund.

Marketing that attracts The Schemer:

Do you make promises or commitments to your customers? Offer extras, incentives or bonuses to get customers to work with you? Schemers look for incomplete policies and procedures.

If you’re a designer and you don’t offer source files, state that specifically. Do you create single use websites or can your customers turn around and resell your work? State your boundaries clearly, then prepare to defend them.

 

Defending your business starts with awareness

Want to protect your business from these nightmare predators? Learn to recognize the symptoms. When you’re aware of the problem it’s easier to spot the solution. But what then? Do you show these predators the door? It depends. If you don’t have a strategy or plan in place to deal with these predators it’s a good idea to show them the door.

What if you need the money?

Or, you have a plan to deal with these predators? It’s rare, but some of them can be converted into all-stars. It requires all of the ingredients I mentioned earlier and the strength to stand up to anything they throw at you.

But it can be done.

If you’re in a situation where you need the money or you have to work with a predator? Here’s a few ways to protect yourself.

  • Get paid up front. Get 50 to 75 percent of the project paid up front. Get paid via credit or debit card, so you control when you’re paid. Bill them weekly or bi-weekly to minimize potential damage if they decide not to pay.
  • Make your agreement ironclad. Make it non-negotiable. Predators sign it as-is or you walk. Add in clauses where the agreement auto renews indefinitely or until you cancel. Give yourself the ability to walk away at any time.
  • Close the loopholes. Find all of the loopholes in your marketing, in your policies and procedures. Then close them.
  • Freeze everything when they step out of line. Did they give you a faulty credit card? Stop working. Asking for something questionable or unethical? Stop working.

Walking away is ideal; have a strategy in place if you can’t. Predators don’t have to take you for a ride. You can provide the help they need and survive to tell the story. Manipulation and abuse doesn’t have to be an option you accept.

 

The customer from hell is a predator

Predators are abusive, entitled and demanding. They choose their victims carefully. They’ll do their best to spend as little as possible while simultaneously squeezing as much free work out of you as they can. You don’t have to be their next victim.

You have the power. Now you’re aware of their attacks, you know where they’ll strike. That awareness acts as a vaccine, giving you the knowledge you need to protect your business and your customers. But only if you choose your customers carefully.

Want to protect your business from these nightmare predators? Learn to recognize the symptoms. When you’re aware of the problem it’s easier to spot the solution. But what then? Do you show these predators the door? It depends. If you don’t have a strategy or plan in place to deal with these predators it’s a good idea to show them the door.

What if you need the money?

Or, you have a plan to deal with these predators? It’s rare, but some of them can be converted into all-stars. It requires all of the ingredients I mentioned earlier and the strength to stand up to anything they throw at you.

But it can be done.

If you’re in a situation where you need the money or you have to work with a predator? Here’s a few ways to protect yourself.

  • Get paid up front. Get 50 to 75 percent of the project paid up front. Get paid via credit or debit card, so you control when you’re paid. Bill them weekly or bi-weekly to minimize potential damage if they decide not to pay.
  • Make your agreement ironclad. Make it non-negotiable. Predators sign it as-is or you walk. Add in clauses where the agreement auto renews indefinitely or until you cancel. Give yourself the ability to walk away at any time.
  • Close the loopholes. Find all of the loopholes in your marketing, in your policies and procedures. Then close them.
  • Freeze everything when they step out of line. Did they give you a faulty credit card? Stop working. Asking for something questionable or unethical? Stop working.

Walking away is ideal; have a strategy in place if you can’t. Predators don’t have to take you for a ride. You can provide the help they need and survive to tell the story. Manipulation and abuse doesn’t have to be an option you accept.

 

The customer from hell is a predator

Predators are abusive, entitled and demanding. They choose their victims carefully. They’ll do their best to spend as little as possible while simultaneously squeezing as much free work out of you as they can. You don’t have to be their next victim.

You have the power. Now you’re aware of their attacks, you know where they’ll strike. That awareness acts as a vaccine, giving you the knowledge you need to protect your business and your customers. But only if you choose your customers carefully.

cmis:value.sf:invariantValue:
Have you ever had a customer from hell? The kind of customer who abuses you, spending as little as they possibly can while trying to squeeze as much free work out of you as possible?

You’re not alone.

At some point, most creative professionals (e.g. designers, developers, copywriters, etc.) will run into the customer from hell. These are the customers who, once they’re inside your business, bring in 20 percent of your income and 80 percent of your headaches.

Customers today are abusive, entitled and demanding… right? Actually no…

Customers as a whole are patient, kind and understanding. When they buy into you, into your business, they’re game changers. These customers have the power to literally change your business for the better, over night. I just mentioned the customer from hell though. Am I talking out both sides of my mouth? Not at all: The customers from hell? They aren’t customers…they’re predators.

These customers come in five deadly flavors, but their goal is the same. Take as much as they can from you, give as little as they can in return. Ruthless and simple. What’s not so simple is how they find you.

Most people have serious misconceptions about these predators. Their mistaken ideas keep them in the dark, which is exactly what these thirsty bloodsuckers want. Most of us recognize these predators when they’re in our business, but by then it’s too late.

If you’re clueless about them, you’re clueless about how they work — which means you can’t stop them, especially if you believe in these myths:

  • It’s a customer service issue: “If we’re just able to keep them happy we won’t have a problem.”
  • All customers are basically good: “If we’re good to them they’ll be good to us.”
  • Make customers the priority: “Put customers first and they’ll reward you” or “the customer is always right.”

So what’s the problem then? What attracts them to your business?

Marketing. Haphazard marketing sucks these predators in. The term “marketing” means anything you’re doing to close new clients. Your emails, proposals, blog posts, forum posts, anything. 

And the worst part?

Most freelancers have no idea their marketing attracts the wrong customer. But how? Are these predators all the same? Should you work with them or weed them out? Knowing who you’re fighting dictates how you fight.

Let’s start with the first predator.

 

1) The Arranger (manipulates deals, circumstances and events)

These predators want any project, any circumstance to be win/lose in their favor. If you have an agreement they’ll change the terms and conditions. They demand options that don’t exist and push for concessions that really only benefit them.

The Arranger looks for two things:

  • Freelancers afraid to lose their business. Every project is an amazing opportunity when there aren’t enough clients. Arrangers use this fear to wear you down, chipping away at you until you’re psychologically exhausted.
  • An unhealthy desire to be flexible. Need this 300 page site in 48 hours? Sure! Established freelancers use a “take it or leave it” philosophy. Arrangers use “flexible freelancers” as cheap labor.

 

2) The Corrupter (a dirty, rotten liar)

They’ll say or do anything to get what they want. They’ll lie to you or about you. They’ll steal from you, turn customers and vendors against you, use entrapment – nothing is off limits for them.

The Corrupter looks for two things:

  • Fear of Conflict. The Corrupter loves to cross the line. They’ll invade your boundaries, cross ethical and moral lines and provoke fights. Carefully monitoring your response. A fear of conflict tells them it’s okay to steam roll over you.
  • Unfair exchange. Give Corrupters a discount, concession or deal and they keep pushing. Put conditions or limits on what you’re willing to give them and they become vicious.

 

3) The Disrupter (demands control)

These predators require special treatment. They want to be in charge. They refuse to use your product or service as intended. They demand your co-workers, partners or employees ignore your requests. For Disrupters, control is everything.

Marketing that attracts The Disrupter:

Disrupters target freelancers with strong “peace keeping” or “fun loving” temperaments. Prefer to avoid conflict or focus on having fun? Disrupters demand you do things their way.

Messages like “have it your way”, “designed around you” and “you’re the boss” are lightning rods that attract The Disrupter.

If you’re a freelancer with a strong perfectionist or control temperament, you’re much harder to control. Focus on “keeping the peace” to win a customer and you’re theirs.

 

4) The Slanderer (punishes you with shame and guilt)

The Slanderer is a professional troll. They’ll provoke you. Imply that you’ve let them down. They’ll bully you, spread gossip and pick fights—they want you to explode.

When you do they have the justification they need to demand discounts, ask for free products and “renegotiate” contracts: “Why do you charge 10x as much for the same service?” “I gave you a chance when no one else would. Is this how you repay me?” “My company pays your bills.” “How do you justify not including that feature? That’s robbery!”

Marketing that attracts The Slanderer:

As a freelancer you’re unique. That’s obvious to you but it’s something customers can’t see. What’s worse, your uniqueness needs to accomplish two clear goals.

  • Something customers care about. Your uniqueness solves customer problems or attracts them in some way.
  • They’re willing to pay for it. It tells you that customers value your work and they’re willing to take a risk with you.

Marketing pieces that say things like “we guarantee your satisfaction”, “we never stop working for you” or “our customers are number one” attract slanderers.

They see this lack of uniqueness as potential desperation. They believe there’s nothing special about you as a freelancer. So they’ll remind you over and over in different ways, until they’re able to get what they want.

 

5) The Schemer (exploits loopholes)

Agreements were created for them. They’re incredibly resourceful; they’ll find a way over, under, around or through your boundaries. Don’t do spec work? “You should have told me.” Offer a 30 day money back guarantee? They’ll use your rules against you. They’ll squeeze out 60 days of free work, then on day 59 ask for a full refund.

Marketing that attracts The Schemer:

Do you make promises or commitments to your customers? Offer extras, incentives or bonuses to get customers to work with you? Schemers look for incomplete policies and procedures.

If you’re a designer and you don’t offer source files, state that specifically. Do you create single use websites or can your customers turn around and resell your work? State your boundaries clearly, then prepare to defend them.

 

Defending your business starts with awareness

Want to protect your business from these nightmare predators? Learn to recognize the symptoms. When you’re aware of the problem it’s easier to spot the solution. But what then? Do you show these predators the door? It depends. If you don’t have a strategy or plan in place to deal with these predators it’s a good idea to show them the door.

What if you need the money?

Or, you have a plan to deal with these predators? It’s rare, but some of them can be converted into all-stars. It requires all of the ingredients I mentioned earlier and the strength to stand up to anything they throw at you.

But it can be done.

If you’re in a situation where you need the money or you have to work with a predator? Here’s a few ways to protect yourself.

  • Get paid up front. Get 50 to 75 percent of the project paid up front. Get paid via credit or debit card, so you control when you’re paid. Bill them weekly or bi-weekly to minimize potential damage if they decide not to pay.
  • Make your agreement ironclad. Make it non-negotiable. Predators sign it as-is or you walk. Add in clauses where the agreement auto renews indefinitely or until you cancel. Give yourself the ability to walk away at any time.
  • Close the loopholes. Find all of the loopholes in your marketing, in your policies and procedures. Then close them.
  • Freeze everything when they step out of line. Did they give you a faulty credit card? Stop working. Asking for something questionable or unethical? Stop working.

Walking away is ideal; have a strategy in place if you can’t. Predators don’t have to take you for a ride. You can provide the help they need and survive to tell the story. Manipulation and abuse doesn’t have to be an option you accept.

 

The customer from hell is a predator

Predators are abusive, entitled and demanding. They choose their victims carefully. They’ll do their best to spend as little as possible while simultaneously squeezing as much free work out of you as they can. You don’t have to be their next victim.

You have the power. Now you’re aware of their attacks, you know where they’ll strike. That awareness acts as a vaccine, giving you the knowledge you need to protect your business and your customers. But only if you choose your customers carefully.

cmis:propertyString.cmis:value:
¿Alguna vez ha tenido un cliente del infierno? El tipo de cliente que abusa de ti, pasar tan poco como les sea posible al tratar de exprimir trabajo tanto libre de ti como sea posible?

No estas solo.
En algún momento, la mayoría de los profesionales creativos (por ejemplo, diseñadores, desarrolladores, redactores, etc.) se ejecutará en el cliente del infierno. Estos son los clientes que, una vez que están dentro de su negocio, traen en el 20 por ciento de sus ingresos y el 80 por ciento de sus dolores de cabeza.
Los clientes de hoy están abusivo, derecho y exigente ... ¿verdad? En realidad no…
Los clientes en su conjunto son pacientes, amables y comprensión. Cuando compran en que, en su negocio, que son cambiadores de juego. Estos clientes tienen el poder de cambiar literalmente su negocio para mejor, durante la noche. Acabo de mencionar el cliente del infierno sin embargo. ¿Estoy hablando a cabo ambos lados de la boca? De ninguna manera: Los clientes del infierno? No son clientes ... son depredadores.

Estos clientes vienen en cinco sabores mortales, pero su objetivo es el mismo. Tome todo lo que pueden de su parte, dar tan poco como sea posible a cambio. Implacable y sencilla. Lo que no es tan simple es la forma en que se encuentran.
La mayoría de las personas tienen graves conceptos erróneos acerca de estos depredadores. Sus ideas equivocadas a mantenerse en la oscuridad, que es exactamente lo que estas sanguijuelas sedientas quieren. La mayoría de nosotros reconocemos estos depredadores cuando están en nuestro negocio, pero para entonces ya es demasiado tarde.

Si estás desorientado sobre ellos, eres ni idea acerca de cómo funcionan - lo que significa que no se puede dejar de ellos, sobre todo si se cree en estos mitos:
Es un problema de servicio al cliente: "Si sólo somos capaces de mantenerlos felices no vamos a tener un problema."
Todos los clientes son básicamente buenas: "Si estamos bien a los que van a ser bueno para nosotros."

Hacer que los clientes la prioridad: "poner a los clientes en primer lugar que va a recompensar usted" o "el cliente siempre tiene la razón."
Entonces, ¿cuál es el problema entonces? Lo que los atrae a su negocio?
Márketing. comercialización fortuita chupa estos depredadores. El término "comercialización" significa algo que está haciendo para cerrar nuevos clientes. Sus correos electrónicos, propuestas, blogs, mensajes en el foro, cualquier cosa.

Y la peor parte?
La mayoría de los trabajadores independientes no tienen idea de su comercialización atrae al cliente equivocado. ¿Pero cómo? Son estos depredadores de todos modos? En caso de trabajar con ellos o eliminar a cabo? Sabiendo que estás luchando dicta cómo se lucha.

Vamos a empezar con el primer depredador.
 
1) La Arreglista (manipula ofertas, circunstancias y eventos)
Estos depredadores quieren cualquier proyecto, cualquier hecho que hay que ganar / perder a su favor. Si usted tiene un acuerdo que va a cambiar los términos y condiciones. Exigen opciones que no existen y empujan por las concesiones que en realidad sólo se benefician de ellos.

La Arreglista busca dos cosas:
Los trabajadores independientes tienen miedo de perder su negocio. Cada proyecto es una oportunidad increíble cuando no hay suficientes clientes. Arreglistas utilizan este miedo a agotar su paciencia, saltando lejos en usted hasta que esté psicológicamente agotados.
Un deseo malsano de ser flexible. Necesita este sitio de 300 páginas en 48 horas? ¡Por supuesto! autónomos establecidos utilizan un "lo tomas o lo dejas" filosofía. Arreglistas utilizan "flexibles" autónomos como mano de obra barata.
 
2) El Corruptor (una sucia, podrida mentiroso)
Van a decir o hacer cualquier cosa para conseguir lo que quieren. Ellos se encuentran a usted o sobre usted. Ellos roban a usted, a su vez clientes y proveedores en contra de usted, use atrapamiento - nada está fuera de límites para ellos.

El Corruptor busca dos cosas:
El miedo al conflicto. El Corruptor ama a cruzar la línea. Ellos invaden sus límites, líneas éticas y morales cruz y provocan peleas. monitoreo cuidadoso de su respuesta. Un miedo al conflicto les dice que está bien en vapor pase el cursor sobre ti.
intercambio desigual. Corruptores dar un descuento, concesión o contrato y seguir presionando. Poner condiciones o límites en lo que está dispuesto a dar a ellos y que se convierte en vicioso.
 
3) El control disruptor (demandas)
Estos depredadores requieren un tratamiento especial. Ellos quieren estar a cargo. Se niegan a usar su producto o servicio según lo previsto. Exigen sus compañeros de trabajo, socios o empleados ignoran sus peticiones. Para alteradores, el control es todo.

Marketing que atrae el disruptor:
Disruptores dirigen a los trabajadores independientes con un fuerte "mantenimiento de la paz" o "temperamentos amantes de la diversión". Prefieren evitar el conflicto o se centran en la diversión? Disruptores exigen que hagas las cosas a su manera.
Mensajes como "Haz lo que quieras", "diseñado pensando en usted" y "usted es el jefe" son los pararrayos que atraen el disruptor.

Si usted es un profesional independiente con un fuerte temperamento perfeccionista o control, es mucho más difícil de controlar. Centrarse en "mantener la paz" para ganar un cliente y usted es el suyo.
 
4) El Calumniador (que castiga con la vergüenza y la culpa)
El Calumniador es un troll profesional. Ellos te provocan. Implica que usted los ha defraudado. Te van a intimidar, chismes difundir y recoger peleas que quieren que explotar.

Al hacerlo tienen la justificación que necesitan para exigir descuentos, pedir productos libres y "renegociar" los contratos: "¿Por qué cobran 10 veces más por el mismo servicio?" "Te di una oportunidad cuando nadie más lo haría. ¿Es así como me lo pagas? "" Mi empresa paga sus facturas. "" ¿Cómo se justifica que no incluyen esta característica? Eso es un robo! "

Marketing que atrae al calumniador:
Como un profesional independiente que eres único. Eso es obvio para usted, pero es algo que los clientes no pueden ver. Lo que es peor, su singularidad necesita para lograr dos objetivos claros.

los clientes se preocupan por algo. Su singularidad resuelve problemas de los clientes o los atrae de alguna manera.

Están dispuestos a pagar por ello. Se da a conocer que los clientes valoran su trabajo y que están dispuestos a tomar un riesgo con usted.

piezas de marketing que dicen cosas como "te garantizamos su satisfacción", "nunca dejamos de trabajar para usted" o "nuestros clientes son el número uno" atraer a los calumniadores.

Ven esta falta de singularidad como la desesperación potencial. Ellos creen que no hay nada especial acerca de usted como un profesional independiente. Así que van a recordarle una y otra de diferentes maneras, hasta que son capaces de conseguir lo que quieren.
 
5) El Schemer (explota las lagunas)
Acuerdos fueron creados para ellos. Son increíblemente ingeniosa; que van a encontrar una manera de encima, por debajo, alrededor oa través de sus fronteras. No realice trabajos de especificaciones? "Debería haberme dicho." Ofrecer una garantía de devolver el dinero de 30 días? Ellos usarán sus reglas en contra de usted. Van a exprimir los 60 días de trabajo libre, a continuación, en el día 59 piden un reembolso completo.

Marketing que atrae el intrigante:
¿Haces promesas o compromisos con sus clientes? Ofrecen extras, incentivos o bonificaciones para llegar a los clientes trabajar con usted? En definitiva, los buscan las políticas y procedimientos incompletos.
Si usted es un diseñador y no se ofrecen archivos de origen, estado que específicamente. Cómo se crea sitios web de un solo uso o de sus clientes puede dar la vuelta y volver a reservar su trabajo? Afirman sus límites claramente, a continuación, se preparan para defenderlos.
 
La defensa de su negocio comienza con la conciencia
¿Quiere proteger su negocio de estos depredadores de pesadilla? Aprender a reconocer los síntomas. Cuando usted es consciente del problema que es más fácil de detectar la solución. Pero lo que entonces? ¿Le muestra a estos depredadores de la puerta? Depende. Si usted no tiene una estrategia o un plan en marcha para hacer frente a estos depredadores es una buena idea para mostrarles la puerta.

¿Qué pasa si usted necesita el dinero?
O usted tiene un plan para hacer frente a estos depredadores? Es raro, pero algunos de ellos se puede convertir en todas las estrellas. Se requiere que todos los ingredientes que he mencionado antes y la fuerza para hacer frente a cualquier cosa que tirar de ti.
Pero puede hacerse.

Si estás en una situación en la que necesita el dinero o usted tiene que trabajar con un depredador? He aquí algunas maneras de protegerse.

Se les paga por adelantado. Consigue 50 a 75 por ciento del proyecto pagado por adelantado. Se les paga a través de tarjeta de crédito o débito, por lo que controlar el momento en que le pagan. Bill todas las semanas o cada dos semanas para minimizar el daño potencial si deciden no pagar.

Haga su acuerdo férreo. Que sea no negociable. Los depredadores firman como está o se puede caminar. Añadir en las cláusulas donde el auto acuerdo renueva indefinidamente o hasta que cancele. Dése la capacidad de caminar de distancia en cualquier momento.

Colmar las lagunas. Encontrar todos los resquicios de su comercialización, en sus políticas y procedimientos. A continuación cerrarlas.

Congelar todo cuando se pasan de la raya. ¿Le dieron una tarjeta de crédito defectuoso? Para de trabajar. Pidiendo algo cuestionable o no ético? Para de trabajar.
El irse es ideal; tener una estrategia en su lugar si no se puede. Los depredadores no tienen que le llevará a dar un paseo. Puede proporcionar la ayuda que necesitan y sobrevivir para contar la historia. La manipulación y el abuso no tiene que ser una opción de aceptar.
 
El cliente del infierno es un depredador
Los depredadores son abusivos, titulado y exigente. Ellos eligen a sus víctimas con cuidado. Que van a hacer todo lo posible para pasar tan poco como sea posible al momento de apretar al mismo tiempo la mayor cantidad de trabajo libre de ti como pueden. Usted no tiene que ser su próxima víctima.
Tu tienes el poder. Ahora usted es consciente de sus ataques, ya sabe dónde van a huelga. Esa conciencia actúa como una vacuna, que le da el conocimiento que necesita para proteger su negocio y sus clientes. Pero sólo si elige cuidadosamente a sus clientes.
